executive_summary: Operators in the Protective Eyewear Manufacturing industry manufacture safety glasses, protective goggles and face shields to safeguard eyes from debris, chemicals, radiation and blood-borne pathogens. The industry exists primarily because of regulations that require employers to supply protective equipment to their employees. While these regulations have supported industry revenue, declines in the overall manufacturing sector have caused revenue declines during the previous five-year period. Over the five years to 2021, industry revenue is expected to increase at an annualized rate of just 0.5% to $635.9 million.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue growth slow due to manufacturing declines
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry has not performed well over the past five years due to declines in downstream manufacturing and construction markets, with revenue expected to rise only 0.5% annually to $635.9 million over the five years to 2021.

Demand depends on regulations requiring employers to provide protective eyewear, enforced by OSHA and other agencies following standards set by ANSI. More stringent regulations have been developed over the past decade.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Key markets are manufacturing, construction, healthcare
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Major markets include manufacturing (30% of revenue), construction (23.6%), and healthcare/research (11.2%). Demand from healthcare has increased as it is relatively recession-proof.

High manufacturing costs and import competition have led to consolidation, with major companies acquiring smaller manufacturers. The number of establishments is expected to decline 0.8% annually over the five years to 2021.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Positive outlook as major markets accelerate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The outlook is largely positive as major markets like construction and healthcare continue growing. However, import competition and rising material costs will limit growth, with revenue projected to rise only 0.7% annually to $658.1 million over the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturing and construction demand to increase
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand is expected to grow from expanding manufacturing, mining, and construction markets as economic activity increases. The construction market in particular is anticipated to boost demand rapidly.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Healthcare market to represent larger share
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The healthcare market, including medical personnel and researchers requiring protective eyewear, is expected to make up around 15% of industry revenue by 2026 as the sector continues growing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Focus on higher value-added and innovative products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To maintain profit margins, US manufacturers will likely focus on developing more advanced, higher value-added products with greater functionality and design elements like tinted lenses and prescription safety glasses.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that manufacture protective eyewear. This category primarily includes safety glasses and goggles that are used in laboratories, construction and mining to protect employees from chemical splashes, debris, optical radiation and high heat hazards.

negative_impact_factors: Low and steady level of assistance

threats: Price of plastic materials and resin

key_trends: Demand also depends on employers who seek to reduce the incidence of injury
As a result of import competition and slowing demand from downstream markets, the number of industry establishments is expected to fall
Consolidation has helped the industry retain margins
Healthcare will continue to represent a growing sector of the US economy
US-based companies will likely focus on higher value-added activities and develop more advanced products to maintain profit
Prescription safety glasses will increase their share of revenue, representing a growth segment
While regulations have supported revenue, declines in the overall manufacturing sector have caused revenue declines

market_segmentation.segment_description: The majority of safety glasses and goggles are distributed to the manufacturing and mining sector. IBISWorld estimates that this sector will account for 30.0% of total industry revenue in 2021.

Employees within the construction sector are another large end market for protective eyewear products. This sector includes carpenters, electricians, masonry and other construction workers. In 2021, IBISWorld expects this sector to generate 23.6% of total industry revenue.

Staff employed at healthcare and laboratory research facilities make up another significant market for the industry. IBISWorld expects that this sector will account for 10.4% of total industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Sales of protective goggles generate an estimated 27.6% of the industry's revenue. Goggles provide more protection than safety glasses from optical radiation, impact, dust, liquid splash and high heat hazards, since they form a protective seal for both eyes.

Safety glasses are the most common form of eyewear protection; the segment generates an estimated 48.0% of the Protective Eyewear Manufacturing industry's revenue. Safety glasses are used to protect eyes from dust, chips or flying particles.

Prescription safety glasses generate an estimated 8.2% of industry revenue. Prescription safety glasses are designed for individuals who also require vision correction. Prescription safety glasses are a growth segment for the industry due to the increasing need among employees for vision correction.

Face shields account for an estimated 16.2% of the industry's total revenue. They are a secondary form of protection that is typically used in conjunction with glasses or goggles. Face shields are commonly used with heat, chemical, radiation or impact hazards.

tier_1_suppliers: Plastic & Resin Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Glass Product Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Laboratory Supply Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Supplies Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Regulation changes focusing on workplace safety
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for the Protective Eyewear Manufacturing industry in the United States is primarily driven by regulation changes focusing on workplace safety. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets general requirements for protective equipment.

Demand for protective eyewear manufacturing is also driven by employment changes in high-risk occupations. These occupations primarily include construction, manufacturing, mining and laboratory settings.
Employment trends in manufacturing are another key determinant of demand for eyewear protection. Employees in the manufacturing sector have the highest rates of eye injuries on the job.

Employees involved in laboratory research and healthcare fields are also prone to eye-related injuries. The transmission of infectious diseases through the membranes of the eye is one of the primary risks.

Research is mainly driven by trends in research and development expenditure. Over the past five years, research and development expenditure has risen at an annualized rate of 1.6%, contributing to demand for safety goggles and face shields required for research with sensitive chemicals or infectious diseases.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States is a net importer of safety goggles, glasses and other protective eyewear. The top two sources of imports are China and Taiwan, which together account for 73.4% of industry imports. Imports from China have increased by $120.0 million since 2016.

IBISWorld estimates that between 2016 and 2021, exports of industry products will decrease at an annualized rate of 6.2%. This was seen with exports declining as a share of revenue from 29.6% in 2016 to 21.0% in 2021.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region holds an estimated 17.2% of the industry's facilities, with major company Honeywell International Inc. headquartered in New Jersey.

regulations_points.regulation_title: OSHA eye and face protection standards
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) requires employers to provide employees with eyewear meeting ANSI Z87.1 standards when exposed to debris, chemicals, liquids, vapors or radiation.
The Mine Safety and Health Administration requires all miners to wear safety glasses, goggles or face shields when in the mine or plant.
The U.S Food and Drug Administration sets guidance for industry manufacturers regarding impact-resistant lenses.
ANSI standards have been revised multiple times, with major changes in 2010 to coverage requirements, flammability testing, and product markings.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Capital requirements for starting a new business
barriers_points.barrier_description: There are high capital costs required to manufacture safety glasses and goggles. Certified goggles require specific absorptive dyes to provide adequate protection. Besides materials, skilled labor is an important requirement resulting in high labor costs.
Several industry regulations govern the manufacturing of protective eyewear products.

basis_points.basis_description: Price is one of the most important competitive factors. Producers with economies of scale and purchasing power can negotiate lower input costs to produce lower-cost products.
Product quality is significant as the industry provides safety products where ability to withstand impact, splashes, pathogens etc. is critical.

Timeliness, speed of delivery and after-sales service are integral for generating repeat sales. Location of facility and proximity to customers is important for meeting deadlines and reducing transportation costs.
Ability to provide a range of safety glasses, goggles and face shields to various industries is important. Companies with more extensive product range may experience reduced revenue volatility.
There is a moderate level of technological innovation in developing new products with enhanced safety features, tinted lenses etc.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 companies account for 65.3% revenue share
concentration_points.concentration_description: In 2021, the top four companies in the industry are expected to account for 65.3% of total revenue.
Market share concentration has been on the rise as major companies pursue mergers and acquisitions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest cost to industry manufacturers. In 2021, purchases are expected to account for 40.4% of the industry's total revenue. Protective eyewear manufacturers typically purchase plastic resins, lens blanks, plastic sheets and rods.
The price of plastic resin is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 0.1% over the five years to 2021.

Polycarbonate is the standard material used for frames and lens. Trivex, similar to polycarbonate, is thin, lightweight and more impact-resistant than regular plastic or glass lenses. However, Trivex lenses provide clearer optics and can easily be tinted.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Dependent on skilled specialists and engineers
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The majority of industry operators are dependent on skilled specialists and engineers that test and design protective eyewear, which must comply with federal, state and industry-specific regulations.
Ophthalmic goods are often custom made, especially as markets increase their demand for prescription and design-oriented safety glasses.

The average industry company currently allocates 20.5% of their revenue toward wages, while capital depreciation consumes a share of 1.7%. IBISWorld estimates that the average industry enterprise spends $0.08 in capital investment for every $1.00 spent in wages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuating demand from construction and manufacturing
volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry market demand from construction and manufacturing customers can fluctuate slightly depending on economic cycles.
The introduction of new eye protective equipment standards and regulations require customers to purchase new equipment over a short period of time as they seek to comply.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Stable demand from healthcare and research
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility is lessened by more stable demand markets such as healthcare facilities and research laboratories.
Fixed workplace regulations mean that demand cannot fall drastically because employers cannot risk noncompliance by withholding protective equipment purchases.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: One of the most significant changes was the introduction of Trivex in 2001 by PPG Industries Inc. Trivex is an alternative material to polycarbonate for frames and lenses.
Companies have increasingly developed prescription safety glasses over the past decade to address vision correction needs.
Other areas of innovation include new lightweight product lines for comfort and tinted lenses for outdoor use.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: The depreciating US dollar has led to reduced competition from imports.

FAQs.question: Did your company focus on other products during the pandemic?
Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Protective eyewear products are typically made using plastic materials.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Most companies do not command significant market share.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Some eyewear producers have reduced costs through new technology such as additive manufacturing.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Some simple parts of the manufacturing process can be automated to reduce costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Industry manufacturers must follow strict safety rules, given the nature of their products.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies work with trade associations that represent safety product manufacturers.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit margins are impacted by fluctuations in commodity prices.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Eyewear manufacturers must upgrade equipment to promote innovation.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have? Do you have a high turnover rate?
FAQs.answer: The production of ophthalmic equipment requires a highly skilled labor force. Skilled labor reduces the frequency of errors, improving brand image and strengthening brand loyalty.

FAQs.question: How much time is invested in research and development? What are the costs associated with this? Does your company use the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: To bring innovative products to market and expand revenue, companies must invest in a high level of research and development.

FAQs.question: Has your company developed export markets? If so, is there capacity to increase export volumes? If not, is exportation an option for your company?
FAQs.answer: The ability to identify growth opportunities overseas, especially in Latin America and Asian countries, will be a key factor for company growth.

FAQs.question: Does your company track fluctuations in the trade-weighted index? How does your company adapt when the value of the US dollar is strong?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the countries it trades with. The industry generally benefits from a strong dollar.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating plastic material and resin prices affect your company? Are certain products more affected than others when prices fluctuate?
FAQs.answer: As input costs rise, industry operators typically raise prices to maintain profit margins. As a result, when the price of plastic rises, companies increase prices and generate higher revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in the industrial production index? How does your company adjust when the industrial production index decreases?
FAQs.answer: The industrial production index measures the output from the mining, manufacturing, electric and gas industries. Increased industrial activity translates to greater demand for protective equipment.
